title: Derived traits do not need to depend on phantom type parameters.
body:
Let's say I have the following struct definition:

    #[derive(Debug, Copy, Clone, PartialEq, Eq, Hash)]
    struct Object<T> {
        x: i32,
        _t: PhantomData<T>,
    }

According to the book, the `derive`d implementations of `Debug` etc., all of which can be broken down recursively, would simply check that the members `x` and `_t` implement the respective trait. What I'm seeing is if I provide a type to the "phantom" type parameter `T` which does not implement one of these traits, then `Object<T>` will not be derived an implementation of that trait, though the `PhantomData` type, as a zero-sized and effectively a "dummy" type, implements all of these traits without dependency on its type parameter.

For example: Create an instance of `Object<i32>`. `T=i32` which implements `Copy`, so you can therefore `Copy` the parent object. In contrast, try `Object<String>`. `String` does not implement `Copy`, and this causes `Object<String>` to not receive a `Copy` implementation although it most certainly can.

EDIT: Playground examples - [`Object<i32>` implements `PartialEq`](http://play.rust-lang.org/?gist=435fc900a60bc00117bc2d584a0e562a&version=stable&mode=debug), but [`Object<std::io::Stdin>` does not.](http://play.rust-lang.org/?gist=ce87ca7b818e9ac24bd4af1ec8a1c6e0&version=stable&mode=debug)
